column2: There was no string, but I frolicked along with my master to the Twenty-third street ferry.
column3: There was no string, but I frolicked along with my master to the Twenty third street ferry.

column2: And the cats on the route saw reason to give thanks that prehensile claws had been given them.
column3: And the cats on the route saw reason to give thanks that prehensile claws had been given them.

column2: On the Jersey side my master said to a stranger who stood eating a currant bun:
column3: On the Jersey side my master said to a stranger who stood eating a currant bun:

column2: Me and my doggie, we are bound for the Rocky Mountains.
column3: Me and my doggie, we are bound for the Rocky Mountains.

column2: But what pleased me most was when my old man pulled both of my ears until I howled, and said:
column3: But what pleased me most was when my old man pulled both of my ears until I howled, and said:

column2: You common, monkey-headed, rat-tailed, sulphur-coloured son of a door mat, do you know what I'm going to call you?
column3: You common, monkey headed, rat tailed, sulphur coloured son of a door mat, do you know what I'm going to call you?

column2: I thought of "Lovey," and I whined dolefully.
column3: I thought of "Lovey," and I whined dolefully.

column2: I'm going to call you 'Pete,' says my master; and if I'd had five tails I couldn't have done enough wagging to do justice to the occasion.
column3: I'm going to call you 'Pete,' says my master; and if I'd had five tails I couldn't have done enough wagging to do justice to the occasion.

column2: THE LOVE-PHILTRE OF IKEY SCHOENSTEIN
column3: THE LOVE PHILTRE OF IKEY SCHOENSTEIN

column2: The Blue Light Drug Store is downtown, between the Bowery and First Avenue, where the distance between the two streets is the shortest.
column3: The Blue Light Drug Store is downtown, between the Bowery and First Avenue, where the distance between the two streets is the shortest.

column2: The Blue Light does not consider that pharmacy is a thing of bric-a-brac, scent and ice-cream soda.
column3: The Blue Light does not consider that pharmacy is a thing of bric a brac, scent and ice cream soda.

column2: If you ask it for pain-killer it will not give you a bonbon.
column3: If you ask it for pain killer it will not give you a bonbon.

column2: The Blue Light scorns the labour-saving arts of modern pharmacy.
column3: The Blue Light scorns the labour saving arts of modern pharmacy.

column2: It macerates its opium and percolates its own laudanum and paregoric. To this day pills are made behind its tall prescription desk--pills rolled out on its own pill-tile, divided with a spatula, rolled with the finger and thumb, dusted with calcined magnesia and delivered in little round pasteboard pill-boxes.
column3: It macerates its opium and percolates its own laudanum and paregoric. To this day pills are made behind its tall prescription desk-pills rolled out on its own pill tile, divided with a spatula, rolled with the finger and thumb, dusted with calcined magnesia and delivered in little round pasteboard pill boxes.

column2: The store is on a corner about which coveys of ragged-plumed, hilarious children play and become candidates for the cough drops and soothing syrups that wait for them inside.
column3: The store is on a corner about which coveys of ragged plumed, hilarious children play and become candidates for the cough drops and soothing syrups that wait for them inside.

column2: Ikey Schoenstein was the night clerk of the Blue Light and the friend of his customers.
column3: Ikey Schoenstein was the night clerk of the Blue Light and the friend of his customers.

column2: Thus it is on the East Side, where the heart of pharmacy is not glace.
column3: Thus it is on the East Side, where the heart of pharmacy is not glace.

column2: There, as it should be, the druggist is a counsellor, a confessor, an adviser, an able and willing missionary and mentor whose learning is respected, whose occult wisdom is venerated and whose medicine is often poured, untasted, into the gutter.
column3: There, as it should be, the druggist is a counsellor, a confessor, an adviser, an able and willing missionary and mentor whose learning is respected, whose occult wisdom is venerated and whose medicine is often poured, untasted, into the gutter.

column2: Therefore Ikey's corniform, be-spectacled nose and narrow, knowledge-bowed figure was well known in the vicinity of the Blue Light, and his advice and notice were much desired.
column3: Therefore Ikey's corniform, be spectacled nose and narrow, knowledge bowed figure was well known in the vicinity of the Blue Light, and his advice and notice were much desired.

column2: Ikey roomed and breakfasted at Mrs. Riddle's two squares away.
column3: Ikey roomed and breakfasted at mrs Riddle's two squares away.

column2: Mrs. Riddle had a daughter named Rosy.
column3: mrs Riddle had a daughter named Rosy.

column2: The circumlocution has been in vain--you must have guessed it--Ikey adored Rosy.
column3: The circumlocution has been in vain-you must have guessed it-Ikey adored Rosy.

column2: She tinctured all his thoughts; she was the compound extract of all that was chemically pure and officinal--the dispensatory contained nothing equal to her. But Ikey was timid, and his hopes remained insoluble in the menstruum of his backwardness and fears.
column3: She tinctured all his thoughts; she was the compound extract of all that was chemically pure and officinal-the dispensatory contained nothing equal to her. But Ikey was timid, and his hopes remained insoluble in the menstruum of his backwardness and fears.

column2: Behind his counter he was a superior being, calmly conscious of special knowledge and worth; outside he was a weak-kneed, purblind, motorman-cursed rambler, with ill-fitting clothes stained with chemicals and smelling of socotrine aloes and valerianate of ammonia.
column3: Behind his counter he was a superior being, calmly conscious of special knowledge and worth; outside he was a weak kneed, purblind, motorman cursed rambler, with ill fitting clothes stained with chemicals and smelling of socotrine aloes and valerianate of ammonia.

column2: The fly in Ikey's ointment (thrice welcome, pat trope!) was Chunk McGowan.
column3: The fly in Ikey's ointment (thrice welcome, pat trope!) was Chunk McGowan.

column2: Mr. McGowan was also striving to catch the bright smiles tossed about by Rosy.
column3: mr McGowan was also striving to catch the bright smiles tossed about by Rosy.

column2: But he was no outfielder as Ikey was; he picked them off the bat. At the same time he was Ikey's friend and customer, and often dropped in at the Blue Light Drug Store to have a bruise painted with iodine or get a cut rubber-plastered after a pleasant evening spent along the Bowery.
column3: But he was no outfielder as Ikey was; he picked them off the bat. At the same time he was Ikey's friend and customer, and often dropped in at the Blue Light Drug Store to have a bruise painted with iodine or get a cut rubber plastered after a pleasant evening spent along the Bowery.

column2: One afternoon McGowan drifted in in his silent, easy way, and sat, comely, smooth-faced, hard, indomitable, good-natured, upon a stool.
column3: One afternoon McGowan drifted in in his silent, easy way, and sat, comely, smooth faced, hard, indomitable, good-natured, upon a stool.

column2: Ikey, said he, when his friend had fetched his mortar and sat opposite, grinding gum benzoin to a powder, "get busy with your ear. It's drugs for me if you've got the line I need."
column3: Ikey, said he, when his friend had fetched his mortar and sat opposite, grinding gum benzoin to a powder, "get busy with your ear. It's drugs for me if you've got the line I need."

column2: Ikey scanned the countenance of Mr. McGowan for the usual evidences of conflict, but found none.
column3: Ikey scanned the countenance of mr McGowan for the usual evidences of conflict, but found none.

column2: Take your coat off, he ordered.
column3: Take your coat off, he ordered.

column2: I guess already that you have been stuck in the ribs with a knife.	I guess already that you have been stuck in the ribs with a knife.
column3: true

column2: I have many times told you those Dagoes would do you up."
column3: I have many times told you those Dagoes would do you up."

column2: Mr. McGowan smiled.
column3: mr McGowan smiled.

column2: Not them, he said.
column3: Not them, he said.

column2: Not any Dagoes.	Not any Dagoes.
column3: true

column2: But you've located the diagnosis all right enough--it's under my coat, near the ribs.
column3: But you've located the diagnosis all right enough-it's under my coat, near the ribs.

column2: Say!
column3: Say!

column2: Ikey--Rosy and me are goin' to run away and get married to-night."
column3: Ikey-Rosy and me are goin' to run away and get married to night."

column2: Ikey's left forefinger was doubled over the edge of the mortar, holding it steady.
column3: Ikey's left forefinger was doubled over the edge of the mortar, holding it steady.

column2: He gave it a wild rap with the pestle, but felt it not. Meanwhile Mr. McGowan's smile faded to a look of perplexed gloom.
column3: He gave it a wild rap with the pestle, but felt it not. Meanwhile mr McGowan's smile faded to a look of perplexed gloom.

column2: That is, he continued, "if she keeps in the notion until the time comes.
column3: That is, he continued, "if she keeps in the notion until the time comes.

column2: We've been layin' pipes for the getaway for two weeks.
column3: We've been layin' pipes for the getaway for two weeks.

column2: One day she says she will; the same evenin' she says nixy.
column3: One day she says she will; the same evenin' she says nixy.

column2: We've agreed on to-night, and Rosy's stuck to the affirmative this time for two whole days.
column3: We've agreed on to night, and Rosy's stuck to the affirmative this time for two whole days.

column2: But it's five hours yet till the time, and I'm afraid she'll stand me up when it comes to the scratch."
column3: But it's five hours yet till the time, and I'm afraid she'll stand me up when it comes to the scratch."

column2: You said you wanted drugs, remarked Ikey.
column3: You said you wanted drugs, remarked Ikey.

column2: Mr. McGowan looked ill at ease and harassed--a condition opposed to his usual line of demeanour.
column3: mr McGowan looked ill at ease and harassed-a condition opposed to his usual line of demeanour.

column2: He made a patent-medicine almanac into a roll and fitted it with unprofitable carefulness about his finger.
column3: He made a patent medicine almanac into a roll and fitted it with unprofitable carefulness about his finger.

column2: I wouldn't have this double handicap make a false start to-night for a million, he said.
column3: I wouldn't have this double handicap make a false start to night for a million, he said.

column2: I've got a little flat up in Harlem all ready, with chrysanthemums on the table and a kettle ready to boil.	I've got a little flat up in Harlem all ready, with chrysanthemums on the table and a kettle ready to boil.
column3: true

column2: And I've engaged a pulpit pounder to be ready at his house for us at 9.30.
column3: And I've engaged a pulpit pounder to be ready at his house for us at nine point three zero.

column2: It's got to come off.
column3: It's got to come off.

column2: And if Rosy don't change her mind again!"--Mr.
column3: And if Rosy don't change her mind again!"--mr

column2: McGowan ceased, a prey to his doubts.
column3: McGowan ceased, a prey to his doubts.

column2: I don't see then yet, said Ikey, shortly, "what makes it that you talk of drugs, or what I can be doing about it."
column3: I don't see then yet, said Ikey, shortly, "what makes it that you talk of drugs, or what I can be doing about it."

column2: Old man Riddle don't like me a little bit, went on the uneasy suitor, bent upon marshalling his arguments.
column3: Old man Riddle don't like me a little bit, went on the uneasy suitor, bent upon marshalling his arguments.

column2: For a week he hasn't let Rosy step outside the door with me.	For a week he hasn't let Rosy step outside the door with me.
column3: true

column2: If it wasn't for losin' a boarder they'd have bounced me long ago.
column3: If it wasn't for losin' a boarder they'd have bounced me long ago.

column2: I'm makin' $20 a week and she'll never regret flyin' the coop with Chunk McGowan."
column3: I'm makin' twenty dollars a week and she'll never regret flyin' the coop with Chunk McGowan."

column2: You will excuse me, Chunk, said Ikey.
column3: You will excuse me, Chunk, said Ikey.

column2: I must make a prescription that is to be called for soon.
column3: I must make a prescription that is to be called for soon.

column2: Say, said McGowan, looking up suddenly, "say, Ikey, ain't there a drug of some kind--some kind of powders that'll make a girl like you better if you give 'em to her?"
column3: Say, said McGowan, looking up suddenly, "say, Ikey, ain't there a drug of some kind-some kind of powders that'll make a girl like you better if you give 'em to her?"

column2: Ikey's lip beneath his nose curled with the scorn of superior enlightenment; but before he could answer, McGowan continued:
column3: Ikey's lip beneath his nose curled with the scorn of superior enlightenment; but before he could answer, McGowan continued:

column2: Tim Lacy told me he got some once from a croaker uptown and fed 'em to his girl in soda water.	Tim Lacy told me he got some once from a croaker uptown and fed 'em to his girl in soda water.
column3: true

column2: From the very first dose he was ace-high and everybody else looked like thirty cents to her.
column3: From the very first dose he was ace high and everybody else looked like thirty cents to her.

column2: They was married in less than two weeks."
column3: They was married in less than two weeks."

column2: Strong and simple was Chunk McGowan.
column3: Strong and simple was Chunk McGowan.

column2: A better reader of men than Ikey was could have seen that his tough frame was strung upon fine wires. Like a good general who was about to invade the enemy's territory he was seeking to guard every point against possible failure.
column3: A better reader of men than Ikey was could have seen that his tough frame was strung upon fine wires. Like a good general who was about to invade the enemy's territory he was seeking to guard every point against possible failure.

column2: I thought, went on Chunk hopefully, "that if I had one of them powders to give Rosy when I see her at supper to-night it might brace her up and keep her from reneging on the proposition to skip.
column3: I thought, went on Chunk hopefully, "that if I had one of them powders to give Rosy when I see her at supper to night it might brace her up and keep her from reneging on the proposition to skip.

column2: I guess she don't need a mule team to drag her away, but women are better at coaching than they are at running bases.
column3: I guess she don't need a mule team to drag her away, but women are better at coaching than they are at running bases.

column2: If the stuff'll work just for a couple of hours it'll do the trick."
column3: If the stuff'll work just for a couple of hours it'll do the trick."

column2: When is this foolishness of running away to be happening? asked Ikey.
column3: When is this foolishness of running away to be happening? asked Ikey.

column2: Nine o'clock, said Mr. McGowan.
column3: Nine o'clock, said mr McGowan.

column2: Supper's at seven.	Supper's at seven.

column2: At eight Rosy goes to bed with a headache.
column3: At eight Rosy goes to bed with a headache.

column3: At nine old Parvenzano lets me through to his back yard, where there's a board off Riddle's fence, next door.

column2: I go under her window and help her down the fire-escape.
column3: I go under her window and help her down the fire escape.

column2: We've got to make it early on the preacher's account.
column3: We've got to make it early on the preacher's account.

column2: It's all dead easy if Rosy don't balk when the flag drops.
column3: It's all dead easy if Rosy don't balk when the flag drops.

column2: Can you fix me one of them powders, Ikey?"
column3: Can you fix me one of them powders, Ikey?"

column2: Ikey Schoenstein rubbed his nose slowly.
column3: Ikey Schoenstein rubbed his nose slowly.

column2: Chunk, said he, "it is of drugs of that nature that pharmaceutists must have much carefulness.
column3: Chunk, said he, "it is of drugs of that nature that pharmaceutists must have much carefulness.

column2: To you alone of my acquaintance would I intrust a powder like that.
column3: To you alone of my acquaintance would I intrust a powder like that.

column2: But for you I shall make it, and you shall see how it makes Rosy to think of you."
column3: But for you I shall make it, and you shall see how it makes Rosy to think of you."

column2: Ikey went behind the prescription desk.

column2: There he crushed to a powder two soluble tablets, each containing a quarter of a grain of morphia.
column3: There he crushed to a powder two soluble tablets, each containing a quarter of a grain of morphia.

column2: To them he added a little sugar of milk to increase the bulk, and folded the mixture neatly in a white paper.
column3: To them he added a little sugar of milk to increase the bulk, and folded the mixture neatly in a white paper.

column2: Taken by an adult this powder would insure several hours of heavy slumber without danger to the sleeper. This he handed to Chunk McGowan, telling him to administer it in a liquid if possible, and received the hearty thanks of the backyard Lochinvar.
column3: Taken by an adult this powder would insure several hours of heavy slumber without danger to the sleeper. This he handed to Chunk McGowan, telling him to administer it in a liquid if possible, and received the hearty thanks of the backyard Lochinvar.

column2: The subtlety of Ikey's action becomes apparent upon recital of his subsequent move.
column3: The subtlety of Ikey's action becomes apparent upon recital of his subsequent move.

column2: He sent a messenger for Mr. Riddle and disclosed the plans of Mr. McGowan for eloping with Rosy.
column3: He sent a messenger for mr Riddle and disclosed the plans of mr McGowan for eloping with Rosy.

column2: Mr. Riddle was a stout man, brick-dusty of complexion and sudden in action.
column3: mr Riddle was a stout man, brick dusty of complexion and sudden in action.

column2: Much obliged, he said, briefly, to Ikey.
column3: Much obliged, he said, briefly, to Ikey.

column2: The lazy Irish loafer!	The lazy Irish loafer!

column2: My own room's just above Rosy's.
column3: My own room's just above Rosy's.

column2: I'll just go up there myself after supper and load the shot-gun and wait.

column2: If he comes in my back yard he'll go away in a ambulance instead of a bridal chaise."
column3: If he comes in my back yard he'll go away in a ambulance instead of a bridal chaise."

column2: With Rosy held in the clutches of Morpheus for a many-hours deep slumber, and the bloodthirsty parent waiting, armed and forewarned, Ikey felt that his rival was close, indeed, upon discomfiture.
column3: With Rosy held in the clutches of Morpheus for a many hours deep slumber, and the bloodthirsty parent waiting, armed and forewarned, Ikey felt that his rival was close, indeed, upon discomfiture.

column2: At eight o'clock in the morning the day clerk arrived and Ikey started hurriedly for Mrs. Riddle's to learn the outcome.

column2: I sat down at the supper table last night at Riddle's, and I looked at Rosy, and I says to myself, 'Chunk, if you get the girl get her on the square--don't try any hocus-pocus with a thoroughbred like her.' And I keeps the paper you give me in my pocket.
